tit.cmt: 門跡（もんせき、もんぜき）→Webster's Online Dictionary

sen.j: 門跡（もんせき、もんぜき）とは、日本の仏教の開祖の正式な後継者。
sen.e: Monzeki or Monseki means the formal successor of founder of Buddhism sect in Japan.
"Monzeki" or "monseki" means the formal successor of the founder of a Buddhist sect in Japan.
"Monzeki" or "Monseki" means the formal successor of the founder of a Buddhist sect in Japan.

sen.cmt: 門葉門流→定訳不明 kotobank

sen.j: 鎌倉時代以降は位階の高い寺院そのもの、つまり寺格を指すようになり、それらの寺院を門跡寺院と呼ぶようになった。
sen.e: Since Kamakura Period, it became to mean the high class temple itself, that is, the status of temple, and those temples became to be called Monzeki Temples.
sen.cmt: 鎌倉時代→英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: Since the Kamakura period it has come to mean the high-class temple itself, that is, the status of the temple, and those temples have come to be called monzeki temples.
Since the Kamakura period it has come to mean the high-class temple itself, or in other words the status of the temple, and those temples have come to be called Monzeki temples.

sen.j: 宇多天皇が出家して仁和寺に入室し御室御所と称し、御室門跡となったのが始まりである。
sen.e: It was the beginning that Emperor Uda became priest and lived in Ninna-ji Temple to be called Omuro-gosho, and became to be called Omuro-Monzeki.
It was in the beginning that Emperor Uda became priest and lived in Ninna-ji Temple (therefore called Omuro-gosho), and came to be called Omuro-Monzeki.
It was in the beginning that Emperor Uda became priest and lived in Ninna-ji Temple (therefore called Omuro-gosho), and came to be called Omuro-Monzeki.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代初期頃からは皇族や摂家等の子弟が特定の寺院に出家するようになる。
sen.e: Since around the beginning of Kamakura Period, children of imperial family and Sekke, line of regents and advisers, became to be priests at the specific temples.
sen.cmt: 皇族→Webster's Online Dictionary、摂家→kotobank, Webster's Online Dictionary、摂家=摂関家（出典：kotobank）
sen.e: Since around the beginning of the Kamakura period, children of the Imperial Family and the sekke (the line of regents and advisers) came to be priests at specific temples.
Since around the beginning of the Kamakura period, children of the Imperial Family and the sekke (the line of regents and advisers) came to be priests at specific temples.

sen.j: 子弟らは荘園を所有しておりその経済力を背景とした政治力をもって、受け入れた寺院内の支配権を掌握するようになり、各門流を継承するようになった。
sen.e: Children had Shoen, i.e., manor, and became to take control of accepted temples by political power due to their economic power so that they became to succeed each Monryu.
sen.cmt: 荘園→Webster's Online Dictionary、門流→定訳不明
sen.e: The children had a shoen (i.e. a manor) and came to take control of accepted temples by political power due to their economic power so that they ultimately came to succeed each monryu.
The children had a Shoen (i.e. a manor) and came to take control of accepted temples by political power due to their economic power so that they ultimately came to succeed each monryu.

sen.j: これらが慣例化してやがて、「門跡」自体が「貴族」出身者によって継承される特定の院家・寺院を指す称号へと変化した。
sen.e: These became a custom and soon 'Monzeki' itself was changed to mean the title of the specific temples which are succeeded by people from 'nobility.'
This became a custom, and soon 'Monzeki' itself was changed to mean the title of the specific temples to which people from the 'nobility' succeeded.
This became a custom, and soon 'Monzeki' itself was changed to mean the title of the specific temples to which people from the 'nobility' succeeded.

sen.j: そして室町時代になると、寺格としての「門跡」が確立し、室町幕府には、門跡寺院に関する政務を執る門跡奉行が置かれた。
sen.e: And in Muromachi Period, 'Monzeki' as a status of temple was established so that Monzeki bugyo (Shogunate administrator, 門跡奉行) to govern Monzeki temples was assigned by Muromachi Shogunate.
sen.cmt: 室町幕府→英辞郎 on the WEB、門跡奉行→定訳不明
sen.e: During the Muromachi period, 'monzeki,' as a status of a temple, was established so that the post of monzeki bugyo (shogunate administrator, 門跡奉行) to govern monzeki temples was assigned by the Muromachi shogunate.

During the Muromachi period, 'Monzeki,' as the status of a temple, was established so that the post of Monzeki bugyo (shogunate administrator, 門跡奉行) to govern Monzeki temples was assigned by the Muromachi shogunate.

sen.j: さらに江戸幕府では、宮門跡、摂家門跡、清華門跡、公方門跡（武家門跡）、准門跡（脇門跡）などに区分して制度化した。
sen.e: In addition, Edo Shogunate institutionalized Monzeki by clarification of miya-monzeki (temples headed by imperial princes, 宮門跡), sekke-monzeki (temples headed by the sekke families, 摂家門跡), seiga-monzeki (temples headed by the seiga families, 清華門跡), kubo-monzeki (公方門跡) or buke-monzki (武家門跡, temples headed by military families), jun-monzeki (准門跡) or waki-monzeki (脇門跡) and so on.
sen.cmt: 江戸幕府→英辞郎 on the WEB、宮門跡→定訳不明http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=zKS6X98iJosC&pg=PA201&lpg=PA201&dq=miya+monzeki&source=bl&ots=G3F-3S5OUv&sig=HREuIFbNPompWlM9fo2I_jRY9Tc&hl=ja&ei=TKkZSsXAI9WIkQWhsaHNBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6、摂家門跡→"定訳不明kotobank, Webster's Online Dictionary"、摂家=摂関家（出典：kotobank）、清華門跡→定訳不明、Yahoo辞書、公方門跡→定訳不明、武家門跡→"定訳不明 Webster's Online Dictionary"、准門跡→定訳不明、脇門跡→定訳不明
sen.e: Additionally, the Edo shogunate institutionalized the monzeki through the clarification of miya-monzeki (temples headed by imperial princes, 宮門跡), sekke-monzeki (temples headed by the sekke families, 摂家門跡), seiga-monzeki (temples headed by the seiga families, 清華門跡), kubo-monzeki (公方門跡) or buke-monzki (武家門跡, temples headed by military families), jun-monzeki (准門跡) or waki-monzeki (脇門跡), etc.

Additionally, the Edo shogunate institutionalized the monzeki through the clarification of miya-monzeki (temples headed by imperial princes, 宮門跡), sekke-monzeki (temples headed by the sekke families, 摂家門跡), seiga-monzeki (temples headed by the seiga families, 清華門跡), kubo-monzeki (公方門跡) or buke-monzki (武家門跡, temples headed by military families), jun-monzeki (准門跡) or waki-monzeki (脇門跡), etc.

sen.j: 三千院（梶井殿、梶井門跡、梨本門跡）
sen.e: Sanzenin Temple (Kaji-dono, Kaji Monzeki, Nashimoto Monzeki)
sen.cmt: 梶井殿→定訳不明、読み不明、梶井門跡→kotobank、三千院→http://www.sanzenin.or.jp/top.html
sen.e: Sanzenin Temple (Kaji-dono, Kaji Monzeki, Nashimoto Monzeki)
Sanzenin Temple (Kajii-dono, Kajii Monzeki, Nashimoto Monzeki)

sen.j: 平等院（浄土宗と兼ねる）

tit.e: Miya-monzeki (宮門跡) or Shinno-monzeki (親王門跡) (temples headed by imperial princes)
tit.cmt: 宮門跡→定訳不明http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=zKS6X98iJosC&pg=PA201&lpg=PA201&dq=miya+monzeki&source=bl&ots=G3F-3S5OUv&sig=HREuIFbNPompWlM9fo2I_jRY9Tc&hl=ja&ei=TKkZSsXAI9WIkQWhsaHNBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6、親王門跡→定訳不明、Webster's Online Dictionary
tit.e: Miya-monzeki (宮門跡) or Shinno-monzeki (親王門跡) (temples headed by imperial princes)
Miya-monzeki (宮門跡) or Shinno-monzeki (親王門跡) (temples headed by imperial princes)

sen.j: 法親王、または入道親王が住職として居住する寺院。
sen.e: The temples in which Hoshinno or Nyudoshinno, i.e., priestly Imperial Prince, lives as a chief priest.
sen.cmt: 法親王→http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=m42TldA_OvAC&pg=PA184&lpg=PA184&dq=hoshinno%E3%80%80prince&source=bl&ots=oQSz_xT-lH&sig=UOuCsa757eeUOt8GvlGkwITppQQ&hl=ja&ei=1LQZSoSVNomPkAW2_mA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2、入道親王→http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=m42TldA_OvAC&pg=PA184&lpg=PA184&dq=hoshinno%E3%80%80prince&source=bl&ots=oQSz_xT-lH&sig=UOuCsa757eeUOt8GvlGkwITppQQ&hl=ja&ei=1LQZSoSVNomPkAW2_mA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2、住職→Webster Online Dictionary
sen.e: The temples in which Hoshinno or Nyudoshinno (i.e. a priestly Imperial Prince) lived as a chief priest.
The temples in which Hoshinno or Nyudoshinno (i.e. a priestly Imperial Prince) lived as a chief priest.

sen.j: 輪王寺、妙法院、聖護院、照高院、青蓮院、三千院、曼珠院、毘沙門堂、円満院、仁和寺、大覚寺、勧修寺、知恩院の13寺院のこと。
sen.e: Thirteen temples of Rinno-ji Temple, Myoho-in Temple, Shogo-in Temple, Shoko-in Temple, Shoren-in Temple, Sanzen-in Temple, Manshu-in Temple, Bishamon-do, Enman-in Temple, Ninna-ji Temple, Daikaku-ji Temple, Kaju-ji Temple, and Chion-in Temple.
The thirteen temples of Rinno-ji, Myoho-in, Shogo-in, Shoko-in, Shoren-in, Sanzen-in, Manshu-in, Bishamon-do, Enman-in, Ninna-ji, Daikaku-ji, Kaju-ji and Chion-in
The thirteen temples of Rinno-ji, Myoho-in, Shogo-in, Shoko-in, Shoren-in, Sanzen-in, Manju-in, Bishamon-do, Enman-in, Ninna-ji, Daikaku-ji, Kaju-ji and Chion-in
It is also called thirteen Monzeki.
They are also called the thirteen monzeki.
They are also called the thirteen monzeki.

sen.j: 実際には親王家に限って入寺するのは輪王寺・仁和寺・大覚寺の3門跡で、その他は摂家からも入寺することができた。
sen.e: Actually only Imperial Prince enters the three Monzeki of Rinno-ji Temple, Ninna-ko Temple and Daikaku-ji Temple while children from Sekke could enter the other Monzeki.
Actually, only the Imperial Prince could enter the three monzeki of Rinno-ji Temple, Ninna-ko Temple and Daikaku-ji Temple, while children from the sekke could enter the other monzeki.
In fact, only the Imperial Prince could enter the three monzeki of Rinno-ji Temple, Ninna-ko Temple and Daikaku-ji Temple, while children from the sekke could enter the other monzeki.

sen.j: 室町時代頃から用いられるようになり、摂家の子弟が住職となる。
sen.e: This word has been used since around Muromachi Period and children from Sekke became chief priests.
This word has been used since around the Muromachi period, and children from the sekke became chief priests.
This word has been used since around the Muromachi period, and children from the sekke became chief priests.

sen.j: 個々の門跡寺院に固有の称号ではなく、その時々の住持の出身を指す。
sen.e: It is not an inherent title of each Monzeki Temple but indicates the descent of the chief priest at that time.
It was not an inherent title of each monzeki temple but instead indicated the descent of the chief priest.
It was not an inherent title of each monzeki temple but instead indicated the descent of the chief priest.

sen.j: 門跡に準ずる格式の寺院のこと。
sen.e: Temples in the status which is second to Monzeki.
Temples of a status second to Monzeki
Temples of a status second to Monzeki

sen.j: または、他の門跡寺に対して従の関係にある門跡寺のこと。
sen.e: Or a Monzeki Temple which is subordinate to the other Monzeki Temple.
Or, a monzeki temple that is subordinate to the other one
Or, a monzeki temple that is subordinate to the other one
It is also called Waki Monzeki.

Shoren-in Temple, Sanzenin Temple, Bishamon-do, Manju-in Temple and Myoho-in Temple

sen.j: 浄土真宗で門跡に准ぜられた東本願寺、西本願寺、佛光寺、専修寺、興正寺の総称。
sen.e: A generic term of Higashi-Hongwan-ji Temple, Nishi-Hongwan-ji Temple, Bukko-ji Temple, Senju-ji Temple and Kosho-ji Temple, which are defined to be second to Monzeki in Jodo Shinshu sect.

This is a generic term for Higashi-Hongwan-ji Temple, Nishi-Hongwan-ji Temple, Bukko-ji Temple, Senju-ji Temple and Kosho-ji Temple, which are defined as being second to the monzeki in the Jodo Shinshu sect.

This is a generic term for Higashi-Hongwan-ji Temple, Nishi-Hongwan-ji Temple, Bukko-ji Temple, Senju-ji Temple and Kosho-ji Temple, which are defined as being second to the monzeki in the Jodo Shinshu sect.
They are also called the five Monto (門徒).
They are also called the five monto (門徒).
They are also called the five Monto (門徒).
sen.cmt: 門徒を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 皇女や貴族の息女が住職となる寺院。
sen.e: The temple of which Princess or a daughter of nobility becomes a chief priest.

sen.j: 比丘尼御所、尼門跡ともいう。
